title: Conversation: Michael Maltzan and Maurice Cox—What Can Architecture Be?
hero_caption: Michael Maltzan Architecture. New Carver Apartments, completed 2009. Courtesy of the architect. Credit: Iwan Baan.
short_description: Join renowned architect Michael Maltzan and Commissioner Maurice Cox of Chicago's Department of Planning and Development for a conversation on the capacity of architecture.
list_description: Join renowned architect Michael Maltzan and Commissioner Maurice Cox of Chicago's Department of Planning and Development for a conversation on the capacity of architecture.
description:
Join renowned architect Michael Maltzan and Maurice Cox, Chicago’s Commissioner of the Department of Planning and Development (DPD), as they discuss the civic capacity of architecture and design in urban contexts. This conversation is moderated by Irene Sunwoo, John H. Bryan Chair and Curator of Architecture and Design. 

Michael Maltzan is interested in architecture’s ability to expand the context, types, and forms of its work. Within the complex social, political, and physical contexts of contemporary cities, he has come to believe that architecture possesses a broad range of capacities that allow it to impact not only a building being made, but also the field itself.

Celebrated for his experience merging architecture, design and politics through public, private and elected positions, Commissioner Maurice Cox leads DPD's economic development, planning and zoning projects. He also fosters community-improvement initiatives across Chicago, especially in under-invested neighborhoods in the South and West sides.

Presented by the Butler-VanderLinden Lecture on Architecture.

About the Speaker
